name: The Longest Journey
description: The Longest Journey is an amazing graphical adventure, where the player controls the protagonist, April Ryan, on her journey between parallel universes.
minimum_requirements: Windows 2000/XP, Pentium 166 MMX , 32 MB RAM, Mouse and Keyboard, 640x480 SVGA high colour (16bit) video card with 2 MB RAM, Windows compatible sound device, 300 MB free hard drive space Recommended: Pentium II, 266 mhz, 64 MB RAM , 3d accelarator card ( Direct 3d compatible ) with 4 MB RAM, 1GB free hard drive space

reviews.review_text: This game is only for patient people who don't mind the old graphics.  I've only recently discovered the universe behind this and Dreamfall and as a real sucker for good stories, I went for the first one in the saga. It blew my god damned mind. You play as April Ryan, an unknowing savior of the two worlds that had been split ages ago. She is able to cross the border between them and is able to fully interact with both of them. You'll meet dozens of interesting people and creatures that are fairly believable and likable. You'll be solving some really tough puzzles that don't compare with what's called puzzle now-a-days. Some mysteries which don't make any sense in the beginning will be revealed and fit so perfectly in the story at the end. Other mysteries stay concealed until now and keep thousands of fans excited for more. I highly recommend playing this one before jumping to the newer Dreamfall games. I give this game the ultimate rating   10/10    In fact, I loved the game so much that I made a complete walkthrough   guide  to it, feel free to check it out if you're seriously interested in buying this game because the tasks can get very confusing sometimes.

My review will only show the amount of hours (very few at time of posting) I've played this on steam, but don't let that fool you into thinking I've never played this game. I've just recently re-discovered it on Steam during the winter sale and couldn't be more excited.  This literally was the first PC game I ever purchased with my own money back in '99. Entire evenings and weekends and school breaks were devoted to this game.  I forgot the name of it years after losing one of the discs (the monster 4 disc collection to install it back then) and used to ask people all the time if they had heard of this game. None had, so I figured I was out of luck.  Yeah, the graphics are dated, but it's still a beautiful game. The voice-acting is phenomenal for the time and pulls you in.  I'm so excited to start the journey over again, this time with my boyfriend watching as I play and getting interested in the lore as well. This type of game is not his 'genre', but he will sit and watch me go through it like he's viewing a movie, and pretty much, that's what this game is good about doing. It's a slow moving movie, with a great plot and characters that you help move along.  I even remembered the rubber ducky outside the window right off! That's how long lasting this game stays with you. I loaded the game, went through the opening sequence, and as soon as April was in her apartment I declared 'There is a rubber duck outside this window that I have GOT to get right now!'  I'm not a puzzle person, at all. So that aspect of the game has always had me pulling my hair out, but I'm excited to take this game on as a 30 year old and not as impatient 14 year old, who'd give up and find a guide online to just get through it.  Long story short: If you love point-and-click stories. Get this one. It is most definitely my favorite of all time. Right after that, find Syberia and Syberia II. They're another series of point-and-click adventure games that I thought were from this same developer and they were very close to the style of The Longest Journey.

While the graphics are outdated I really enjoyed this game. You will get to know the main character April and join her in her adventures in strange fantasy worlds, meet many creatures and interesting people. Great story, the puzzles will keep you busy and there is so much humor and mystery in this game. After many joyful hours of playing The Longest Journey I finished it and can't wait to play the next of the series.

One of the BEST point 'n Click Adventure Games ever. Featuring a unique and strong storyline that never gets old (i have already finished the game like 5 times and i still want to download it again to play). I love every piece of it and i always remember the strong emotions and the bonds that game created between me and the main character. STRONGLY recommended to all the point 'n click adventure fans out there!

I started off playing Dreamfall: The Longest Journey, but felt I couldn't continue without playing the start of the adventure; I'm glad I did! This game holds true to the promise of being submersive and story-rich. I would recommend continuing onto the other 2 games if you enjoyed this one. I absolutely had to finish the story, and I was not disappointed. The point and click allows you to become bonded with the characters (you get to focus more on the story given instead of choices as in the other two games) and when you see/hear references to this game in the other two, your heart will simply swell with the heartfelt memories from The Longest Journey.

This is one of the last games from the Golden Age of adventure games, the genre created by the titles published by Sierra and Lucas Arts. Unfortunately, it does show its age compared to some of the other adventure games, which was the problem for the early 3D games that weren't extremely stylized like Grim Fandango or The Neverhood (both worth checking out).  However, once you can get past the low poly characters and the resolution being what it is, it's very easy to become fully immeresed in the game. That's when the voice acting and story quickly come to the forefront, and you will realize that this game is easily on par with many of the modern games. It's rating is completely is justified.  For only 10$, this game is a steal.

I loved this game and couldn't get enough of it. The story is well written and very intresting, the same goes with the characters. What kept me going was definately the story. This is a vey long game with a lot of gameplay, I played it mostly offline, so the hours doesn't represent the reality.   This game is a typical point-and-click, the puzzles are however quite hard and I honestly had to use a walktrough a couple of times.   if you're looking for a feel-good-game, with a story to die for with a lot of gameplay this is definitely the game or you.

First of all completely disregard my play time as it is way off xD This is my favorite game of all times so I'm not gonna be the least bit objective ;) The story is just amazing and you can fall in love with all the characters, not only April, because each of them has substance.  It is nothing like these newer games which revolve around forgettable characters and sexual connotations/strong graphic scenes or violence. This is a classic adventure from the time when games had soul and you were expected to pay attention to the story for the game to make sense.  The conversations are funny, sad and feel real. The puzzles aren't too complicated and won't drive you to look up walkthroughs or drive you so insane as to forget about the story or the game all together, but they are complicated enough to make you use your brain and not think the creators made this for imbeciles. In this game you don't have to worry about dying or making a fatal error, this is a casual mood and story based adventure for all of us who don't feel like being tense throughout the game. The controls are, as one would expect, very simple. In my pre-Steam era I've played through this game at the very least 50 times, and I'm not exaggerating. I believe I will play it at least as much times now I've gotten it on Steam.

Wow, I honestly am glad to have discovered this gem really late. Considered one of the best Adventure games out there. It is really sad that my game save got deleted out of nowhere despite me attempting to fix my issue, I finished the game by watching a playthrough online. Regardless, I played through the first half and enough to be pulled into the world the developers created, and what a world that is. It has a much more complex story than I had imagined. It is extremely long and the only 7 hours I played was less than half of the game. I blindly recommend this game to any Adventure game fanatic, although not new ones since it might be too overwhelming.
One of the best Adventure games ever created. Finished this Epic Saga in 17 hours.  I especially remember it's great personalities, difficult puzzles, atmospheric environments and immersive Story.
Gigantic. There's no better way to describe this.

I love point and click adventure games, I have played quite a few in my time but none compare to the awesomeness that is The Longest Journey. It has a rich, detailed, deep story that will suck you in and never let you go. It has characters that you will actually care about, gorgeous locations to explore, a stunning soundtrack, brain teasing puzzles and the voice acting ain't half bad either, especially from the protagonist April Ryan (voiced by Sarah Hamilton).  Even if you are not a fan of point and click adventures, I highly recommend you play this game, or at least give the demo a go.

It's starts out veeeery slow (say, first 2-3 chapters?), but the more you play, the more awesome it gets. Especially once you figure out the shortcuts (like how to run, time skip, quick select items from inventory, etc)  It's enjoyable, culturally rich, conceptually rich and fun. The important part is that it's fun! The puzzles aren't that hard to figure out either so it's not one of those frustrating puzzle games.  In regards to characters... I only like 3 characters, including the main character, April. The other characters aren't as endearing or impactful, I suppose.  The ending was a bit lackluster and didn't offer much closure, so I can't wait to play the sequel. 8/10 would recommend you playing this game though!

I had the same problem as a lot of people. Stuttering sound what made the game unplayable. I tried every solution I could find on the internet but nothing helped. But I found the solution! I installed it on my very simple touchscreen laptap (normal and certainly not a gaming laptop) and it works. If you like (old) point and click games like me, you got to get yourself a touchscreen laptop as point and click and touchscreen are a match made in heaven. Probably will save you from RSI as well :). Most of them work on touchscreen but not all. This one works flawlessly, much better then on a normal pc.

One of my all-time favourite games. If you like a mature story of adventure, mixed with humor that is rather low-key, sensible and intelligent, rather than childish, this is your game. The name is not a joke, it is best played slowly, looking at everything, contemplating their meaning and place, etc.  It has a heavy, but warm feel to it. From an age that was better suited to games that welcome the player as an intelligent, mature partner, someone with a brain that can be entertainted with things other than boobs and blood.
One of the greatest point and clicks of all time. Arcadia is such an intriguing setting.

not much to say... its a good adventure game but sometimes i didn't get it and just went on with the story. the main thing is that it's worth your time and puzzeling about in the game makes me always feel like im playing a oldy of my childhood.

If you like point and click adventure games and haven't already played this, you owe it to yourself to give it a try. 'The Longest Journey' is widely considered to be one of the best games in the genre. It follows the story of April Ryan as she travels back and forth between her world of technology and a world of magic that she is mysteriously drawn into. The logic behind the solutions to some of the puzzles can be a bit odd at times, but other than that, I have no real complaints. This game is as fun as I remember it being when it first came out.
Great puzzle game with a rich story and charcaters. Though somewhat old it still holds up very well.

The story is incredibly emotional and complex, it's grounded by epic characters you absolutely fall in love with.  No need to rush; it is a long game takes time to absorb everything.  Burns Flipper <3
A game I just keep comming back for!
The epic saga of April Ryan and the balance of Magic and Science. Audio is good, visuals are awful. An old school Adventure Point and Click in that many of the puzzle have obscure solutions.

This is an amazing point-and-click adventure game. The puzzles are inventive, but usually unintuitive. Graphically it really shows it's age. Despite that, I've replayed this game dozens of times since I first encountered it nearly 15 years ago. The story always pulls me back eventually. One one hand, it's a science-fiction/fantasy mashup that spans several worlds. On the other hand it's the personal story of an extremely well-written protagonist. Those two elements are weaved together perfectly, and that's what makes this game timeless.

This game really is among the very finest 'point-and-click' adventure game that has ever been made. The controls aren't particulary complex. Left-click, right-click, Esc for the save menu, click to skip through dialogue. Pretty standard. The graphics looked dated when the game was new, and by today's standard they're antique. Puzzles are pretty logical, and not very difficult. Death is impossible. But none of that is the reason you want to play this game.  TLJ has one of the most incredible stories ever told in interactive format. It's like playing through an epic-length novel in 15 or 20 hours of gameplay. The voice cast is outstanding from front to back. The lead character, April Ryan, is likable and intelligent, and by the end of the game, you'll feel like you know her, and you'll be sorry to see her go at the end of the game. Despite being dialogue-heavy, this game is never boring. The plot advances with every puzzle solved, every character spoken to. The cultures of two entire worlds are brought into conflict through April Ryan.  April is an art student in a slightly-dystopian, near future version of our world, a high-technology two-class society. Magic doesn't exist there any more than it does in real life. But April gets involved in a complicated plot that finds her being trapped in a parallel universe on a world called 'Arcadia,' where magic is real, and technology is sparse. April occasionally goes back and forth between worlds, and even into space, in order to save Arcadia and her own world, and in the process learns a lot about herself.  Best $10 you could spend on Steam.
Really great game with a nice story!
The beginning of my obsession with a norseman.

For someone who enjoys extreme violence or at the very least automatic weaponary this is really good. Poor April Ryan is a fairly non violent girl but was still a captivating story.  Only marks against it are some of the stupid puzzles. Spock would probably commit suicide if he had to play this, screaming THAT IS ILLOGICAL CAPTAIN.  Oh and they did run out of money near the end as some Spanish Cortez is clearly reused without his accent on another character...

One of the very few games to ever make me cry. The first game out of 3 others was probably the best STORY-wise, and this is coming from someone who initially snubbed this game because of crappy graphics. Dreamfall was amazing with it's story, but I have to admit that this one is better. Granted, the graphics are VERY dated, but they were all the rage in the year 2000. The story is so good though, that after I stopped paying attention to it I got totally absorbed in the story of April Ryan, Stark, Arcadia, Abnaxus, Cortez! Even though this is mostly about April's journey, you'll find yourself caring for the 'backup' characters. I know I did. I love the humor and wit in this, and how it wasn't afraid to be sassy or goofy (without resorting to cheap kid humor).   If you want a game that you'll probably never forget, this is a good one to get. Dreamfall TLJ and Dreamfall Chapters are good too, but trust me, play this first. There is so much that you miss in the other games if you skip this.

Live it as you were reading a book and the game will be really amazing. If you're searching for fast pacing game and difficult enigmas it will be a delusion. The game in itself is just finding things on the screen or put the ones you already have on it, but beside this the story is awasome, good dialogues, good fantasy. I'll how's the next one.
I love this game, but playing it without a walkthrough will make you want to kill yourself.
My favorite game in the world.
Hey.
Absolutely love this game. What a brilliant story, it stayed with me for a long time.
One of the best games ever made indeed. I hate the genre, and it still was glorious.

Although originally released 12 years ago, the Longest Journey is an excellent point-and-click adventure game that has withstood the test of time--if you can ignore how laughable the graphics can be occasionally! It's definitely worth a look-in if you like point-and-click games, and if you enjoy this one, there's a sequel, Dreamfall, to keep you occupied for a few more hours.
Unforgettable story and characters. :)
The pinnacle of 'Point and Click' games. Fantasic story, very likable characters and decent length. Some of the puzzles are a bit obtuse. GameFAQ's is a godsend.

The Longest Journey series has been the best story line game I have ever played in my life. I actually like the original better than the sequal since it involved a lot more thinking, but both are very well done.
Excellent adventure game, best of all I played. Storyline is intriging, puzzles are hard but attractive. The best part is the characters. April is awesome!

This is by far one of the greatest games I've every played, and when you couple it together with dreamfall, it creates a story so immersive that even after the hours upon hours it took to figure out that you do actually need that rubber duck you fished out of your aparment window after all, you still fall head over heels for the game.  As far as gameplay goes, this is your typical point-and-click experience - youve got an inventory filled of stuff (some f it you never even use) and you can use those to solve puzzles. But if gameplay is all you really look for in a game, this isn't for you. The Longest Journey is strictly about story and navigating through the world as the charming and resourceful April Ryan. All in all, I highly recomend this game. It has a story you can't help but become immersed in, fantastic characters, and an origional concept with a very interesting backstory.

I wanted to play Chapters, so I felt I needed to start from the beginning and I am really glad that I did. The game started out slow, but I quickly became sucked into the story. This is probably one of my favorite games ever. The story is great and the puzzles are fun. I definitely want to know the rest of April Ryanâ€™s story.

One of the last great adventure games before the entire genre fell away from the AAA space in the 2000s. Good writing a voicework sell April Ryan as a character, and the twin worlds of Stark and Arcadia strike a careful balance of whimsey and satire (usually) without tipping over into preciousness. Some of the puzzles are of the needlessly convoluted, pixel hunting variety that ultimately killed the genre, but there you go.

One of the best point and click adventure games of it's time, and in most ways it still is one of the best these days. For a title almost 15 years old, some elements of course have become dated - the pre-rendered cutscenes are a clean giveaway - but Ragnar Tornquist's ability for story telling more than makes up for this. He created a universe of two worlds where The Longest Journey tells a great story and lays the groundwork for further developments. Dreamfall neatly expands on this and as of Q4 2012 it is clear that he will work on continuing the story in Dreamfall Chapters. If you are a fan of adventure games and you can appreciate a good story development I would recommend The Longest Journey. It's a great game in and of itself and if you have become involved into the world and characyers, you can continue your experience in the sequels.
Still a great game to play. Worth a replay anytime. One of the all time classic point and click adventures.

This game blew me away.  I'm way late to the party on this title, having only discovered and played through it within the past year or so, but I was shocked at how good it was.  A fantastic world, interesting characters, and a great story are all wrapped together in a single package.  The voice acting is all very well done and adds vibrant life to the various characters you meet throughout your journey.  I would even say this is an adventure title for people who don't think they like adventure titles. I went into this game expecting it to not really be my thing or all that enjoyable, and I really couldn't have been more wrong.  Granted, it's not completely perfect. It's dated, for one thing. You can run it in a windowed mode, but unfortunately there's no option to increase the resolution.  There were some parts in the game that lacked a sense of direction, I found myself getting frustratingly stuck at least a handful of times.  Still, it was all worth it for such a fantastic title.
In my opinion the best Adventure game of all the years. Nothing have brought me so much fun as The Longest Journey. Great dialogues, story and characters. :)
No doubt my favorite game. Couldn't have been complete without Crow.

An amazing classic. The graphics are dated for 2015/2016, but the story is absoutely amazing. Dynamic, fair voice acting, and a steal for the price. This game combines narritive and puzzle solving to keep you occupied rather than subjecting you to endless combat - so if that's your thing you might look elsewhere. If you want an interactive and detailed story without the grind of gearing a character or leveling up - here's your game!

Okay so I think my game is a bit buggy. It won't let me quit and the only way I'm able to get out of the game is shutting down my computer. Buying this game may have been a mistake. The animation is bland but the voice acting is quite good. I like the idea of it. Considering I'm having trouble with it but it's also not the badest game I don't know whether to recommend it or not.
Love this game so much. Just voted for Villain Most In Need Of A Hug Award, because your my boy Roper, my boy!
If you like Blade Runner esque sci-fi and Lord of the Rings esque fantasy, then this point and click adventure game is for you.

The Longest Journey was an old game when I first played it and that was probably about 6 or 7 years ago. Then and now the graphics don't hold up terribly well, but considering that it was launched in 2000 I'd say it's not that bad. However even now the voice acting, story and dialogue are still fantastic after all this time and it's in these areas that Longest Journey truly shines. Like a good book you can't put down, I was sucked into the story immediately and hardly noticed the time passing until looking at the clock to see that it was the middle of the night. The themes are mature and intelligent, the dialogue extremely well crafted, and the characters believable. I almost feel like I need to exhaust all dialogue options because I want experience all of it and to see what the characters say and do in each situation.  It still has faults in the same way that point and click games usually do - the solution for the puzzles are sometimes opaque, or sometimes you know what you need to do but you're pixel-hunting to find where exactly you're supposed to click - but these are problems with the genre and not this particular game. However, there are relatively few of these genre-related problems given how long ago this game was launched.  The one glaring problem that may make this game unplayable for some people is the graphics - if you can't stand fairly blocky character models and low-res textures then this may not be the game for you (just check out the screenshots on the store page to get a good idea). Out of all the re-make games coming out, this is a game that deserves an HD remake. Once you look past the aging graphics however, you will be transported to an incredibly detailed world with an inventive mixture of fantasy and sci-fi in this excellent story.  9.5/10

I'm going to cut the fluff. This is a great point and click adventure with a huge dose of personality in its settings and characters with a deeply layered protagonist. The graphics and gameplay are relics of another era, but they should not deter an enthusiast of science fiction and/or fantasy from partaking in the fascinating adventure of April Ryan.   Warning: A walkthrough will be necessary unless you want to spend hours clicking on random things until the puzzles solve themselves on accident. April is a kleptomaniac, so expect some bizarre things to enter your inventory.

For a title almost 15 years old, some elements of course have become dated - the pre-rendered cutscenes are a clean giveaway - but Ragnar Tornquist's ability for story telling more than makes up for this. He created a universe of two worlds where The Longest Journey tells a great story and lays the groundwork for further developments. Dreamfall neatly expands on this and as of Q4 2012 it is clear that he will work on continuing the story in Dreamfall Chapters. If you are a fan of adventure games and you can appreciate a good story development I would recommend The Longest Journey. It's a great game in and of itself and if you have become involved into the world and characyers, you can continue your experience in the sequels.

Classic point-and-click adventure game with a good story. If youre looking for a kings quest style game with a more present day setting you should check this out. Be warned that it is rather old now, and it is supposed to be the first in a trilogy, but the third game is still a ways off from being released. Also the second game has some pretty strange mechanics.

I played this game back when it came out in 2000; I thought it was older than that but anyway...it was a good game. I had doubts about p[aying a woman (no offense ladies) but the box made the game sound good so I took it home and installed it on my Windows 2000 Pentium II I believe it was, or maybe III. Back then the graphics where pretty awesome. It was an original story happening in two worlds. It held your interest and kept you wanting to play. I bought the game again on Steam (wish I kept all my old games) and played it again. Some parts seemed different and the ending wasn't the way I remembered but It was still a pretty good game. I recommend this game to anyone looking for a good game.
A novel in game form, literally. Charming none the less.
Absolutely beautiful game, just goes to show that graphics don't make a game; definitely a must-play!
Best Story driven point and click game I ever played, Problem is now that I keep coming back to play it :)

The Longest Journey is a point-and-click adventure with an amazing story. This game was made in 1999 but it has a story that can match with some of the better video game stories of today. Not only that, but this gamealso has the greatest voice acting in a video game that I have ever heard in my life. The protagonist April is a lovable character, and the voice acting really makes her seem like that she could be a real person. The game starts out pretty slowly as you learn everything about yourself and the world around you, but it picks up. Some of the puzzles can be a bit obscure, but it doesn't take away from the story. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys point-and-click games or quality storytelling.

I still consider this one of the best games ever made. It's just an incredible... well, journey, that will let you experience two very different worlds. Sure, some puzzles are a bit convoluted, but most actually make sense and pull you in instead of breaking immersion.  Did I mention it has a great story?

I was fortunate enough to have this game gifted to me by a fellow point-and-click enthusiast, and I was really happy to have a chance to play it. I remember playing Sierra's Torrin's Passage when I was a child, and this game hit me with an extra large dose of nostalgia. When it comes to point-and-clickers, The Longest Journey dominates the field and is a classic staple that all people interested in the genre should definitely check out.  If you like point-and-clickers, expansive storylines, and challenging puzzles, then you will really enjoy this game.  The aesthetics are good, but the graphics are very, very dated. Despite this, the environment and the examinable items (in your inventory) remain well-detailed.The character models are a bit lacking, and this is most evident during cutscenes. The music and ambient sounds are approporiate for the themes presented throughout the game, The story is slightly convulted, but also fairly easy to follow if you take the time to read/listen to the dialogue. Your character records her thoughts in a diary, and these can be helpful for summarizing key details and better understanding the story. Each interactable character provides a good amount of backstory and lore. The voice acting is great, but I personally find the main character's voice a bit irritating.  The controls are simple and typical of a pount-and-clicker. There is no tutorial - you are simply dropped into the game, however, it is easy to pick up how to play if you experiment for a few minutes. The learning curve id minimal to moderate - the most difficult thing so far being item combinations (a number of the possible item combos are not obvious). I've also picked up A LOT of items, but their value and use have not yet been determined in my playthough.   The game and story are very cool - the main theme centralizes around two worlds (the magic and non-magic worlds) that can be traversed through 'shifting,' or moving through portals. At the end of each chapter, you are usually presented with a choice of two options, each potentially moving the story in a different direction. Much of the game involves you combining items and giving them to people, or using them to get more items. You can also 'look' at certain items in your inventory, and experimenting with clicks on different areas may yield a new item added to your stash.   You can press 'x' to show all the exits in an area, and this is useful if you don't want to scan with your mouse for different exit points. There is a metro train system, where you can travel to other unlocked areas freely.  Overall, this game provides a very good point-and-click experience, and I suggest you give it a try if you are interested in that particular type of gameplay. The story is well-written and pretty expansive, so you will be spending a lot of time reading/listening to dialogue (all skippable).  Recommend!  Cheers, DJSF  @DJSF's Rogue Reviews

I remember when it first came out and it looked like the most amazing thing ever. Unfortunately back then I was never able to play it. 16 years later though I finally did.  From a story standpoint it is excellent. From a gameplay standpoint... not as much. I'm sure it was groundbreaking when it came out. Now it is just slow. The graphics are dated and I get that, still a good story. The issue with gameplay is it is just too slow. Had the design been tweaked they could have shaved off a LOT of time in painfully slow character animations and such. If you're patient though definetly play this game and the following two sequels.

The best story I have ever played.  I love this game down to my core and it is one of my all time favorites.  However, this game is not for everyone. If you are not patient, this game is not for you. If you require up to date graphics, this game is not for you. If 90's style adventure games with convoluted solutions bother you, this game is not for you. If you do not enjoy both science fiction and fantasy settings, this game is not for you. If you are an open minded person who is interested in playing the one game that most closely encapsulates the feelings of living in a book than any other, this game IS for you.

Created in the late 90's, The Longest Journey is a classic from the golden age of point-and-click adventure games. It is filled with great ideas, interesting well written characters, and a wonderfully immersive world for players to dive into. If you are a gamer who cares about a great story in your games, this is one not to miss.  The gameplay, as you would expect, is of the classic point-and-click type, mainly focusing on talking to various characters, picking up and interacting with various objects, and using those objects in various combinations to solve a range of puzzles to progress the story. In truth, many of the puzzles in this game are obtuse to the point of being annoying, but there are plenty of walkthroughs around if you don't want to beat your head against them and want to simply enjoy the wonderful story. Given that the game was originally released in 1999, its graphics have aged quite badly, even through they were lauded at the time for being pretty cutting edge. Fortunately, point-and-click adventures do not depend heavily on fancy graphics to be playable, so its not a gamebreaking issue. The music and voice acting however, stand up very well, and once you get used to the dated graphics the game remains immensely enjoyable. Given the insignificant price you can get this game for these days, its well worth the investment if you love a good story.
Possibly one of the best games in terms of plot, and characters that I've ever played. Definitely worth giving it a go if you want a good adventure game!
If you liked kings quest or myst, you'll like this.

The game that started it all. No words for this beautiful journey that is sometimes still a mystery and still shaping my thoughts on the future. Also: APRIL RYAN. Alright Buckle Up kidlets. TL:DR ----This game is the game you wanna get if you are willing to be chokeholded and dragged through a rich and deep story driven game. I sat down and spent 13.5 hours playing this game from start to finish. Binged it. All day. I highly recommend this game.  -Onto the meat-  To be honest I did not know what to expect. In my opinion, this is one of the best point-and-click adventures ever made. It is rich with story, with a kickass protagonist and a bad-mouthed companion. It's funny, shocking, and really quite long (4CD's back in the day). You'll get lost in this wonderful world, whether you're jumping in garbage trucks to get into buildings, or attempting to talk with Merpeople. It really is a spectacle.
Seriously good story, awesome characters, and an overall good time! If you're like me, you might need a walkthrough though.
This is an old school point and click game. If you're like me and don't mind old style graphics then it might be for you. Be prepared to use Google to promptly search for what to do while playing.

Even after all these years, The Longest Journey is still, by far, my favourite adventure game ever made. I recently introduced the wife to this game, and after the first 30 minutes she was hooked; we spent an hour (or, what was supposed to be an hour) playing it every night after work until we completed it. Then we bought the sequels - but nothing will ever compare to the joy that is The Longest Journey
The Longest Journey is a storytelling preciious gem that is totally playable even today due to it's cast of amazing characters.
With the closure of Dreamfall Chapters, our journey ends. Yet our life still goes on, chatacters in the game will accomoany us.  It's a fantastic fairy tell you should never miss.
This game was an instant classic for me. Between the world(s), the characters, and the story, the game's impression lasted with me well beyond the ending and inspired story ideas of my own.

Varying parts odd, silly, dark, and poignant. If you're a fan of other offbeat fantasy worlds like Jim Henson's Labyrinth or The Neverending Story, you'll probably like this. Featuring a multi-dimensional female protagonist, an engaging plot, and some really great art.

Through playing this I learned that I loathe point-and-click games. I needed to use a walkthrough for most of the game so I wouldn't waste time on strange and nonsensical 'puzzles.' It's a shame because they did their best to run against the grain of mainstream tropes and really spent quality time on the dialogue and character development. If only the story, with such fleshed-out characters, actually went anywhere with resolution. I finished confused and let down, which was strange considering how much I liked April Ryan.

I was looking forward to an 'adventure' game, not a tedious scavenger hunt for random items and cryptic conversations. I'll give the game props for making April a likable protagonist, but that's about it.

I realize this game is 15 years old, but I'm surprised by what passed as 'entertaining' back then. I have trouble staying awake while playing this game. It is sooo slooow. For example, if you want to make the protagonist, April, walk from one end of an area to the other, you simply click where you want her to walk and then... WAIT. And wait. While she walks. Make that stroll. Saunter? She's obviously in no hurry. Okay, looks like she's finally there now. Now? No, now. There. Several minutes later you can start her walking to her next destination. (Update: Apparently she'll jog if you double click.) Let's see, what else bothered me? Shortly into the game we get to interrogate her landlady in detail about her lesbian lover. That, I'm sure, is pivotal to the plot somehow. When I tried to save the game I would lose my mouse pointer, but luckily I found the enter key worked. I can only exit the game via Task Manager/End Task and when I do, all the font on my desktop reverts to the crappy font from the game.  Rhetorical question: Regarding the abysmally low helpful review rating by the community... Is this because the cons I've listed weren't beneficial in helping you decide on a purchase or just because you love this game and can't stand anyone having a differing opinion on it's worth. Perhaps I should go downgrade all of the thumbs-up reviews... Nah, I'm bigger than that.
You'll spend most of your time walking and walking ... and walking ... and walking ...
